O faire Charites, Joves most deere delight, </br>O lend me now one heaven-inchanting lay, </br>And you rare Nimphes which please Apollos sight, </br>Bring spreading Palme and never-dying Bay, </br>With Olive branches strew the pleasant way: </br>And with your Viols sound one pleasing straine, </br>To ayde his Muse, and raise his humble vaine.

And thou O Beta, Soveraigne of his thought, </br>Englands Diana, let him thinke on thee, </br>By thy perfections let his Muse be taught, </br>And in his breast so deepe imprinted be, </br>That he may write of sacred Chastitie: </br>Though not like Collin in thy Britomart, </br>Yet loves as much, although he wants his arte.

O my dread Soveraigne, rare and princely Mayd, </br>From whose pure eyes the world derives her light, </br>In Angels robes with majestie arayd, </br>In whom true vertue is defin'd aright: </br>O let these lines be gracious in thy sight, </br>In whom alone, as in a perfect glas, </br>All may discerne how chast Matilda was....</br>
